SHADY BUSINESS PRACTICES ENFORCED BY MANAGEMENT. BEWARE.

I‚Äôve brought my family here on two occasions. Today I decided to take my brother. The chef was perfect and so was the waiter initially! I realized that I had no cash and asked the manager ‚ÄúDiamond‚Äù and her assistant where I could get cash ‚Äîas I love tipping servers that way! They directed me down the street and I walked while the meal was being prepared to get cash. The food was delish and fresh as always!
Then I ordered two meals to go- I didn‚Äôt read the menu to see that gratuity was already included so at the end I had tipped the chef cash prior which he deserves! And then I tipped the waiter before almost walking out.

Before walking out I realized they had charged me gratuity (which was my fault for seeing on the menu before that it‚Äôs included ) but not just for the meal I ate in. They PURPOSEFULLY ADDED GRATUITY TO MY TO GO ORDERS!
When I spoke to the manager diamond, she said it was my fault for not asking for a separate check!!!! I told them this was  shady business practices and she instead of apologizing she doubled down and insisted it was my fault. I told her I‚Äôd been a waitress for years and when customers complained, I often followed up with, ‚ÄúI can understand why you‚Äôre upset and we will discuss this with management‚Äù. She did not care.
I asked myself why wouldn‚Äôt they be more apologetic for charging me more accidentally? But i realized that I wasn‚Äôt an accident.

Anyways she didn‚Äôt apologize but she refunded me, I asked back for my cash tip and she ran the check again this time only including gratuity on the dine in meals.

Lastly, when I asked who was above her that I could discuss this forced gratuity on to go orders with she said, ‚Äúit‚Äôs Danny, he‚Äôs not here today, he‚Äôll be here tomorrow but he is going to tell you the exact same thing‚Äù - which is basically we will charge you gratuity on a to go order unless you ask us not to by asking for a separate check.

Long story short: Won‚Äôt be back they tried to take an additional ~$15 in tips illegally. Diamond needs better training as a manager because the way she handled that situation was atrocious. I‚Äôm sure there will be a response to this review by management, I implore you guys to watch the tone of voice towards this matter and ask yourself if that‚Äôs how management should handle complaints especially in regards to something as sensitive as money! These the rules for NY restaurant:

Is adding tips to the bill illegal in NY?

No, adding an automatic gratuity (tip) to a bill, especially for large parties, is generally not illegal in New York, provided certain conditions are met. Restaurants are allowed to add automatic gratuities, but they must clearly disclose this policy to the customer beforehand. This disclosure should be conspicuous, meaning easily noticeable. If the restaurant fails to provide this notice, customers may have a claim under New York's deceptive acts and practices law.

Everything seemed like chaos, I don't know if it was that the fire alarm was carelessly blaring and going off for over 25 minutes before it was shut off.  but the Chef was off, his jokes or the normal hibachi stunts we not on point, he just wanted to cook the food and get out of there. The Chef kept covering his ears while the alarm went off, it seemed like it threw him off. About 18 minutes of the alarms unpleasant and painful sound, I started to get a headache and wanted to leave the place but my spouse convinced me to stay and was a bit upset because we had already been seating down for about 35 minutes. After the alarm stopped, our chef continued to cook, but we were too busy looking at the chef in the other table since he was the only one trying to make the costumers feel comfortable again in the whole restaurant. our cook finished cooking and left quickly. another thing that concerned me was that though someone at our table was allergic to shrimp, all the food was prepared in the front when customarily the persons dish should be cooked in the back and apart for health reasons. Another thing that surprised me was that they didn't even offer a discount or just a free desert for the 25 minute inconvenience of the fire alarm noise. I ended up taking my food home, the headache caused by alarm was unbearable but the food was good the next day. Maybe I will give it a try one day again. who knows.

Flame is a stylish hibachi restaurant that offers a fun and flavorful dining experience at a mid-premium price point, with meals averaging around $50 per person. The chefs entertain with classic hibachi tricks‚Äîthink onion volcanoes and quick knife skills‚Äîwhile grilling fresh, high-quality ingredients like tender steak, juicy shrimp, and perfectly seasoned fried rice right in front of you. The atmosphere is lively, and the service is attentive, making it an ideal spot for both casual nights out and celebratory dinners. While it‚Äôs not the cheapest option, Flame offers great value for the experience and quality of food.
